caption: There’s a friendly gate keeper here who greets most people that come in. The century itself is a great size and it’s on a hill, but the entrance is a little bit hidden and it only has one, so you can walk past it and miss it quite easily.  Is you’re in the area then come and have a wonder here, it will take you about 45 minuets to walk at a slow pace and take in the many different tombs, colourful flowers and trees, as well as the secret views of the church on the hill.

Saint-Vincent Cemetery, located in the picturesque Montmartre neighborhood of Paris, is a hidden gem steeped in history and charm. This intimate cemetery, nestled among cobblestone streets and quaint buildings, offers a peaceful respite from the bustling city. While smaller in scale compared to the famous Père-Lachaise Cemetery, Saint-Vincent Cemetery boasts a unique atmosphere with its tranquil ambiance and beautifully maintained gravesites. Visitors can explore the final resting places of notable figures such as Émile Zola, Adolphe Sax, and Hector Berlioz, reflecting on their contributions to art, literature, and music. Whether strolling through its pathways or admiring its historic monuments, Saint-Vincent Cemetery provides a quiet sanctuary for contemplation and remembrance amidst the vibrant energy of Montmartre.
Nothing much to se here except it a very serene, quiet and a calming place with good vibes.

I have been to many of the cemeteries in Paris over the years, but today, I visited this hidden gem in Montmartre. It is beautiful and peaceful. It is worth your time to think about those buried there, see Sacré Cœur from this perspective, and to just enjoy being alive. This place is worth your time.
Certainly interesting location to explore while at the top of the hill (near the Basilica).
Very calm place. I'd recommend to spend 30 minutes and visit the cemetery
Amazing, very special place. You can feel peace, a lot of quite emocions.
A beautiful nook of Montmartre to spend a few moments.
Very pretty cemetery built on sloping land in Montmartre. Quieter and much smaller than the famous Montmartre cemetery, it is worth a visit. It is only a few minutes' walk from Dalida's bust.
A secret cemetery at the foot of Montmartre. Resting place of late artists and those who built Montmartre.

Are you looking for a final resting place for your old bones? no more hesitation, take a plot at the Saint-Vincent cemetery. With cute neighbors, cute neighbors!!! No more doubt, you are in paradise!!!

Magnificent little cemetery. On the other hand, the guard is really unpleasant to spy on the slightest gestures of visitors. She even called out parents whose little girl was allegedly speaking too loudly. She just spoke with enthusiasm. His presence really stands out with the place. It's a shame.

The Cimetière Saint-Vincent in Montmartre is a small, hidden cemetery that provides a calm and contemplative oasis amidst the vibrant, creative energy of this famous Parisian district. As I step through the iron gates and walk along the cobbled paths, I am immediately enveloped in a deep silence that contrasts sharply with the bustle of Montmartre. The trees that tower over the gravestones and the high walls that surround the cemetery create an intimate atmosphere, almost like a secret garden of remembrance.  The cemetery opened in 1831, when Montmartre was still a separate village outside Paris. It was intended to meet the population's rapidly growing need for a new burial site after the nearby Cimetière de Montmartre became increasingly full. The Cimetière Saint-Vincent is now a much quieter and less visited place than its larger brother, which gives it a special isolation. Despite its modest size and fame, it houses the graves of many well-known personalities, especially from the world of art and culture.  As I stroll through the rows of graves, I notice the names on the tombstones - artists, poets and writers who once considered Montmartre the home of their creative work. One of the most famous residents of this cemetery is the painter Maurice Utrillo, who was born in Montmartre and immortalized the streets and buildings of the district in his paintings. His mother, the artist Suzanne Valadon, one of the few female artists of the early 20th century, is also buried here. Valadon was closely associated with the Parisian art scene, both as an artist and as a model for many important painters of her time, including Renoir and Toulouse-Lautrec.  The cemetery has a strong artistic appeal, not only because of its famous residents, but also because of the ornate tombstones, which are often small works of art themselves. Many of these tombs bear the traces of eras and styles that reflect Montmartre's artistic heyday.  In the narrow, tree-lined paths, I feel the connection between the living and the dead who have chosen Montmartre as their home. The cemetery itself is a reflection of the area's history - from when Montmartre was still a rural village to its heyday as a center of artistic Paris in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.  As I walk along, I think about how much this place represents Montmartre's colorful history. Once a retreat for artists and intellectuals, Montmartre still retains its charm today, although much has changed. The Cimetière Saint-Vincent reminds me that the creative spirits who once lived and worked here remained in some way part of the neighborhood even after their deaths.  The view from the cemetery of the gently sloping hills of Montmartre, lined with small houses and studios, makes me realize why this place has inspired so many artists. The silence of the cemetery, combined with the rich history of its residents, makes it a special place of remembrance and reflection in the otherwise lively Montmartre.  As of: December 22, 2023  *Many people crossed my path in life, only a few left traces, but most, not even a memory.*
Very pleasant little cemetery with a few planted tombs that I really liked. Grave of the artist Maurice Utrillo and Michou.

Smaller cemetery on the hill of Montmartre, not far from the Montmartre vineyard. Among other things, you can find the graves of the painter Maurice Utrillo and the writer Marcel Aymé, in whose honor a square with a sculpture on Montmartre was named. While walking through this cemetery I also discovered many gravestones with extraordinary sculptures. It's worth a visit, although there are much larger and better-known cemeteries in Paris.
It’s a magnificent cemetery, it has Michou as a famous celebrity, and the cemetery toilets are very clean.
A haven of peace in the heart of Montmartre. Very wooded, this cemetery is very well maintained.

A must in Montmartre opened in 1831 and where, among other well-known figures, Maurice Utrillo, Marcel Carné or Ludovic-Rodo Pissaro and very recently Michou rest.  Many characters just as famous but less known to the public such as Nicolas Platon-Argyriades who was a ceramist. To discover in spring with its renewal or in autumn which will delight you with its purple and yellow colors.  To discover.

Located next to Paris's only remaining Montmartre vineyard, the cemetery is home to the grave of Japan's acclaimed painter Maurice Utrillo. This gravestone is the most conspicuous and beautiful tombstone in this cemetery, probably taken care of by the city of Paris.
Very beautiful little cemetery, very colorful in the fall.  If my review and photos helped you, please give me a thumbs up 👍 …

Magnificent little cemetery less known than the one located under the bridge which leads to Place de Clichy but perhaps more charming. We feel that artists have chosen it as their final resting place. There are also surprisingly many olive trees, lavender...which almost gives it a southern feel.

Very beautiful cemetery of modest size, entirely paved and whose paths follow the slope of the Montmartre hill, it is decorated with numerous trees that are still quite young with small identification plaques in French and Latin (nothing to do with the Parisian forest cemeteries like Père Lachaise or Montmartre with their imposing trees). Facing north and showing a larger piece of sky than elsewhere, it houses, in addition to a few graves of musicians and people from cinema and letters, a tomb which is, in my opinion, the most erotic of Parisian cemeteries. Absolute calm as it is sheltered from the noise of the traffic on rue Caulaincourt. A haven of eternal peace of sorts 😉 😇

This small cemetery, located a stone's throw from the vineyards of Montmartre, is absolutely worth visiting. First of all, it is a haven of peace, completely away from traffic. Then, you can discover the tombs of well-known personalities such as the painter Utrillo or the cabaret director Michou. But above all, this cemetery is a real botanical garden! There are many species of trees (17 different species) perfectly labeled, like in a real botanical garden. In short, an enchanted (and free!) interlude which will delight lovers of calm and plants.

At the foot of the Basilica of the Sacré Cœur is this small cemetery, which is very little known even to Parisians, far from the tumult of the city. Where rest personalities who made the history of Montmatre. Recently famous: Michou who contributed to enriching the hill with his famous cabaret restaurant. And I forget other known people (Maurice Utrillo, Marcel Carne....) or unknown. This is in a slightly steep, quiet and well-maintained area.
Difficult to give an opinion on this place as I was not able to try the services. It seems that the residents are satisfied.

A beautiful little cemetery, accessible from the gate in the northwest corner. The first thing you see is the grave of the great Swiss-born composer Arthur Honegger. His most famous work is perhaps the train-themed Pacific 231, but he has also composed 5 absolutely wonderful symphonies and the stage oratorio Jeanne d'Arc au bûcher!
Small cemetery, with a few known people.
Quiet place ideal for a break. Friendly caretaker who can advise you

Small cemetery next to the famous Montmartre cemetery. It benefits from the calm and the shade of the fig trees, which also bring their characteristic scent. It is made up of pretty terraces which can be explored by a path of steps. It is peaceful there, sheltered from the tumult of the capital.
There are some very beautiful statues in this neighborhood cemetery.

Small, well-maintained cemetery with mainly figures from the 1900s-1950s. The very friendly caretaker will give you a map to help you locate the tombs of some famous Parisian figures. Among them, Marcel Aimé (author of the wall pass) and the painter Maurice Utrillo.

"Final destination, as soon as possible!!!" ,, The Saint Vincent Cemetery is a Parisian cemetery located in the Montmartre district. A place with modest proportions and a quiet and silent aspect, It is visited like a museum in front of the tombs of local celebrities (some are real works of art). The entrance located on rue Lucien Gaulard near Place Constantin Pecqueur
I loved visiting this quiet cemetery I felt good right away, I went in and stayed for an hour and didn't even see a single person, just me and I'll be back again, a place to visit
Staff to review Too bad for the tranquility of the place
A small cemetery where Montmartre celebrities are buried. To have

Quiet place, small but nice.
One of the smallest cemeteries in Paris hidden in the corners of Montmartre: a corner of tranquility in the neighborhood.
